newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Philippines' Clark zone mulls debt for development.
newsitem.headline: Philippines' Clark zone mulls debt for development.

text.p: Clark Development Corp is planning to issue $1.0 billion worth of asset-backed securities to partly finance its $8.1 billion development cost spanning over the next 25 years, a Clark official said on Monday.

Clark spokesman Lycette Ramos told Reuters the board of directors had chosen New York-based Clemente Capital Inc to manage the issue of the debt paper to be floated outside the country. The debt flotation is scheduled within the year.
Clark and Clemente Capital are yet to finalise the details of the issue.
Ramos said other financing will come from internally generated revenues and contributions from the state-owned Bases Conversion Development Authority.
Clark receives lease fees from companies operating inside the 4,400-hectare free port zone and a three percent share of the revenues of duty-free shops.

Last week, Clark unveiled its development plan under which the biggest expenditures will be on the upgrading of its 2,200-hectare international airport worth $2.8 billion, and the railway linking Clark with Manila, which is estimated to cost $3.7 billion.
Another $1.6 billion will be used to build residential and recreational facilities, mixed-use buildings, and industrial plants.
The development of the freeport area is expected to yield $70 billion income in the next 30 years, the masterplan showed.
A total of $5.8 billion cumulative income is projected to come from the airport operation, while $64.8 billion cumulative income is forecast from the use of the different facilities.
